graph.title: Graph
graph.text: A graph is a collection of vertices connected by edges.

vertex.title: Vertex
vertex.text: A vertex is a point or node that is part of a graph.

edge.title: Edge
edge.text: Edges are the lines that connect vertices (points) in a graph.

directed.title: Directed Graph
directed.text: In a directed graph, every edge as an arrow, i.e. a start vertex and an end vertex.

subgraph.title: Subgraph
subgraph.text: A graph is a subgraph of another graph, if it is formed by a subset of the larger graphs edges and vertices.

complete.title: Complete Graph
complete.text: In complete graphs, every vertex is connected to every other vertex. A complete graph with n vertices has n × (n – 1)2 edges.

bipartite.title: Bipartite Graph
bipartite.text: Bipartite graphs consists of two sets of vertices. Every vertex is connected to all the vertices in the opposite set, but none of the vertices in its own set.

proof.title: Proof
proof.text: A proof is a logical argument that shows beyond any doubt that a certain statement is true or false.

polyhedron.title: Polyhedron
polyhedron.text: A polyhedron is a three-dimensional solid that only has (flat) polygons as faces. For example, a cube and a pyramid are polyhedra, but a sphere is not.

polygon.title: Polygon
polygon.text:
A polygon is a shape which is bounded by straight lines. For example, a square is a polygon but a circle is not.

If all the sides of a polygon have the same length, it is called a regular polygon.

dna.title: DNA
dna.text:
DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid) is a molceule that contains the genetic blueprint of all living organisms. Most DNAs consist of two strands forming a double helix.

Genetic information is encoded in the order of four nucleic acids (A, G, C and T) which make up the DNA.

DNA sequencing is the process of extracting this information – an essential technique in biology, medicine, genetics and biotechnology.

np.title: NP Hard Problems
np.text:
Computational complexity theory is about determining how “difficult” problems are to be solved by a computer.

“NP hard” (Non-deterministic Polynomial-time hard) is the class of the most difficult problems.

order.title: Order
order.text: The order of a graph is the number of vertices in it.

degree.title: Degree
degree.text: The degree of a vertex is the number of edges that meet at that vertex.

cycle.title: Cycle
cycle.text: Cycles are graphs that consist of a single ring of vertices.

subdivision.title: Subdivisions
subdivision.text: To create a subdivision of a graph you add additional vertices along its edges.

millennium-prize.title: Millennium Prize Problems
millennium-prize.text:
There are seven Millennium Prize Problems which were stated in 2000 by the Clay Mathematics Institute:

  • P vs NP
  • The Hodge Conjecture
  • The Poincaré Conjecture
  • The Riemann Hypothesis
  • Yang-Mills Existence and Mass Gap
  • Navier-Stokes Existence and Smoothness
  • The Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture

Each problem holds $1m prize money. Only one, the Poincaré Conjecture, was solved so far, but the mathematician Grigori Perelman declined the award.
